newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Seoul anti-nuclear group threatens Taiwan boycott.
newsitem.headline: Seoul anti-nuclear group threatens Taiwan boycott.

text.p: South Korean anti-nuclear campaigners threatened a boycott of Taiwanese products on Monday, as Taiwan warned Seoul not to be too pushy.

A 12-member delegation, which included four South Korean members of parliament, arrived in Taipei on Friday to try to press the government to cancel a deal with North Korea to ship up to 200,000 barrels of nuclear waste there.

"We will launch a signature drive in our country to boycott Taiwanese products, and we will tell our residents about the possible danger caused by Taiwan's export of nuclear waste," the delegation said in a departure statement.
The delegation said it will ask the South Korean government to apply stronger pressure on Taiwan over its plan to ship the waste to the impoverished communist state.
South Korea, worried about nuclear contamination on the Korean peninsula, says there is no proof the North -- Seoul's arch-rival -- can store the waste safely.

Taiwan, however, maintains that the waste is is not a health hazard. It also says the Taipei-Pyongyang pact complies with all international regulations and that shipments would be securely contained in steel barrels.
Taiwan's foreign minister John Chang on Monday asked South Korea not to be "too pushy", saying relations between Taipei and Seoul could be hurt if South Korea does not handle the case cautiously.
"South Korea must consider its international image and should not be too pushy," he told reporters here.
Taiwan does not maintain official ties with either South Korea or North Korea.
